items.synopsis: It's the biggest investment most people make, but in the "buyer beware" market, what you see is not always what you get, as these people found out.

title.children: Jade says her 'five-star' house is so defective she considered demolishing it

items.synopsis: South Australia's Department for Child Protection failed to ensure the protection of children was its "paramount consideration" when dealing with more than 90 notifications about two families, the state's ombudsman finds.

title.children: Child protection authorities failed to investigate dozens of red flags in 'tragic reality', report finds

image.altText: A selfie of a woman in a Western Bulldogs top.

items.synopsis: A woman who fatally stabbed her mother in a drunken rage at their home in Adelaide's north could be eligible for parole in less than two years after a judge found there were "exceptional circumstances".

title.children: Daughter jailed for fatally stabbing mother in Adelaide's north

image.altText: A rescuer hangs off the end of a helicopter.

items.synopsis: The news Australia is searching for, and all the news that happened while you snoozed: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Canadian Coast Guard detects more underwater noises, and Dark Mofo strips down for solstice swim. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan is in Boston, Massachusetts, with the latest on the missing submersible. US officials have revealed further "underwater noises" have been detected in the search for a sub still missing in the Atlantic Ocean with five people on board. A Canadian P3 aircraft using sonar buoys yesterday picked up what two US media outlets described as "banging" sounds. The Coast Guard in Boston says further noises have been detected today but it's still too early to say whether or not they're connected to the sub. "When you're in the middle of a search and rescue case, you always have hope. That's why we're doing what we do," Captain Jamie Frederick told reporters. "With respect to the noises specifically, we don't know what they are to be frank with you. "The P-3 detected noises, that's why they're up there, that's why they're doing what they're doing, that's why they put sonar buoys in the water. "The good news is we're searching in the area where the noises were detected and we'll continue to do so." Captain Frederick said two remotely controlled vehicles (ROVs) are already being used in the search zone and more are on the way.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More underwater noises detected in search for sub

props.alt: A press conference with several film cameras photographers and journalists surrounding a man in a lecturn.

children.content: (ABC News: Jade Macmillan)
North America bureau chief
Jade Macmillan
is in Boston, Massachusetts, with the latest on the missing submersible.
US officials have revealed further "underwater noises" have been detected in the search for a sub still missing in the Atlantic Ocean with five people on board.
A Canadian P3 aircraft using sonar buoys yesterday picked up what two US media outlets described as "banging" sounds.
The Coast Guard in Boston says further noises have been detected today but it's still too early to say whether or not they're connected to the sub.
"When you're in the middle of a search and rescue case, you always have hope. That's why we're doing what we do," Captain Jamie Frederick told reporters.
"With respect to the noises specifically, we don't know what they are to be frank with you.
"The P-3 detected noises, that's why they're up there, that's why they're doing what they're doing, that's why they put sonar buoys in the water.
"The good news is we're searching in the area where the noises were detected and we'll continue to do so."
Captain Frederick said two remotely controlled vehicles (ROVs) are already being used in the search zone and more are on the way.
